title: 28.3 Symmetric Positive-Definite Matrices
content:
Section 28.3

Symmetric Positive-Definite Matrices

Summary

Special properties and Cholesky decomposition for SPD matrices.

Key Points

  • SPD: symmetric (A = Aᵀ) and xᵀAx > 0 for all x ≠ 0
  • Cholesky: A = LLᵀ where L is lower triangular
  • No pivoting needed - always stable!
  • Time: O(n³/3) - half the work of LU
  • Applications: covariance matrices, least squares

Example

Covariance matrices are SPD. Cholesky is preferred for stability and efficiency.

Why It Matters

Many optimization and statistics problems have SPD matrices.
